results.title: Riding in cars with boys (Collector's Edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Penny Marshall, Julie Ansell, Laurence Mark, Richard Sakai, Sara Colleton, Columbia Pictures and Grace Films
results.brief_description: Beverly is a 1960s teenager - bright, ambitious and fostering dreams of becoming a writer when she falls pregnant and marries her boyfriend, despite her ambivalence toward him. Feeling trapped in a dreary marriage to an unmotivated drunkard, Beverly seeks to improve her life by studying for a degree - a goal that she hopes will relieve the monotony of her life. Set over twenty years, the film follows Beverly’s mixed fortunes as she struggles with an unfulfilling marriage, thwarted dreams and demands of being a parent. Beverly faces her travails with her best friend Fay, also a teenage mother, with whom she shares many experiences. In the title role Barrymore expresses impish frustration (as opposed to unbridled rage) at the numerous calamities that befall her. With an eventful narrative about family - especially mothers and sons, fathers and daughters - the dramatic intentions of the film, littered with scenes which strive for poignancy, are undermined by the fostering of a lightweight comic tone. In the acting stakes the standouts are Brittany Murphy as Fay and James Woods as Beverly’s dad. Directed by Penny Marshall (Big, A League of their own) and based on the book and true-life experiences of Beverly Donofrio.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Penny Marshall, Julie Ansell, Laurence Mark, Richard Sakai, Sara Colleton, Columbia Pictures and Grace Films

results.title: Riches of the Earth. Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Barry Helmer, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Colourful animation illustrates how Canada’s underground resources took shape through geological ages, and how theses riches of the earth have become our raw materials. We see the formation, by fire, water, wind and ice, of the earth’s crust, with its wealth of minerals, coal, arable land and water.

results.title: Richard St Barbe Baker: man of the trees
results.creator_credit: Leon Narbey, John Maynard and Leon Narbey Productions
results.brief_description: Richard St. Barbe Baker, a 92 year old conservationist known as the “Man of the Trees” leads the campaign to reclaim the world’s deserts and to prevent virgin forests from destruction. Includes footage from his 1952 Sahara crossing and ecological survey and other archival material that sketches his early life and his involvement with conservation in several countries.

results.title: Richard III [study extract]
results.brief_description: This extract shows the opening sequence of “Richard III”, the third of Olivier’s Shakespearian interpretations on film. It remains almost literally as Shakespeare wrote it. Instead of a coldly evil villain as in the stage version, Richard becomes a cocky, artful and almost likeable villain. The opening scene of “Edward VI”, Part 3, is actually the last scene of “Henry VI”, Part 3, and it serves admirably to convey the different levels of court intrigues and tensions and to heighten the effect of Richard’s soliloquy: “Now is the winter of our discontent…” The cast includes Laurence Olivier as Richard and Cedric Hardwicke as Edward IV. Music by William Walton.

results.title: Richard III
results.creator_credit: Laurence Olivier and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: Richard III is the story of one man’s unbridled lust for the crown. Richard’s ambition leaves all who oppose him dead, pawns in his ruthless bid for the throne. This is a majestic film in every sense of the word, and one of the greatest films ever produced in England. Directed by, and starring, Laurence Olivier with Ralph Richardson, Claire Bloom and John Gielgud.

results.title: Ride in the whirlwind
results.creator_credit: Monte Hellman, Jack Nicholson and Proteus Films
results.brief_description: When three innocent cowboys are mistaken for stagecoach robbers, they are forced to become fugitives until they clear themselves of suspicion. Before Jack Nicholson achieved fame in “Easy Rider”, his electrifying talent was evident as the writer, co-producer and star of this taut, highly charged western thriller. Co-starring Cameron Mitchell, Millie Perkins and Harry Dean Stanton.

results.brief_description: Colourful animation illustrates how Canada’s underground resources took shape through geological ages, and how theses riches of the earth have become our raw materials. We see the formation, by fire, water, wind and ice, of the earth’s crust, with its wealth of minerals, coal, arable land and water.

results.title: Rice harvest
results.creator_credit: Bob Lower, Norma Bailey, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Each fall, for generations, the families of the Pauingassi band have camped by northern Manitoba lakes, and combed the reedy shores with brooms, paddles and baskets for manomin - wild rice. The trade with the bush pilot begins the process by which an Indian staple and sacred crop becomes a white man’s luxury food. A quiet but haunting film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Lower, Norma Bailey, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Richard III [McKellen]
results.creator_credit: Richard Loncraine, Lisa Katselas Pare, Stephen Bayly and Richard III Film Company
results.brief_description: Ian McKellen reprises his earlier role as the charismatic but machiavellian Richard of Gloucester, who uses any means necessary to assume the role of King. Director Loncraine provides a contemporary setting of the 1930’s fascist era, providing Shakespear’s traditional tale with a powerfully symbolic and decadent background. Cast includes Annette Bening, Jim Broadbent, Robert Downey Junior, Nigel Hawthorne, Kristin Scott Thomas, Maggie Smith and John Wood.

results.title: Rhythmetron: with the Dance Theatre of Harlem and Arthur Mitchell
results.creator_credit: Milton A. Fruchtman and Capital Cities
results.brief_description: Arthur Mitchell, a leading black dancer, talks about the founding of the Dance Theatre of Harlem in 1970. He speaks of his own struggle for recognition in the white world of ballet. The Company dances parts of three ballets: ‘Fete Noire’, ‘Biosfera’ and ‘Rhythmetron’. Choreography by Arthur Mitchell.
